Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The small invertebrate krill species Thysanoessa inermis is adapted to cold (<math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>) seawater. Over the past ten years, there has been a gradual increase in the water temperature of the krill’s habitat. A sustained increase in water temperature may ultimately affect the ability of the krill to survive. One effect of higher temperatures is protein misfolding within cells. Krill have several <math alttext="h s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> genes that code for heat-shock proteins (<math alttext="H S P s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HSPs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). These proteins help prevent protein misfolding or help to refold proteins to their normal shapes. Scientists conducted experiments on T. inermis to detect changes in the expression of <math alttext="h s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> genes when the krill were exposed to temperatures above <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4°C</mtext></math>. An experimental group of krill was maintained in tanks with <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4°C</mtext></math> seawater and then placed into tanks with <math alttext="10 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>10°C</mtext></math> seawater for approximately three hours. The krill were then given a six-hour recovery period in the <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4°C</mtext></math> seawater tanks. A control group of krill was moved from a tank of <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4°C</mtext></math> seawater to another tank of <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4°C</mtext></math> seawater for approximately three hours and then returned to the original tank. The scientists analyzed <math alttext="h s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene expression by measuring the concentrations of three <math alttext="m R N A s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="1, 2, 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I, II, III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) transcribed from certain <math alttext="h s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> genes in both the heat-shocked krill (Figure 1) and the control krill. For the control krill, no transcription of the <math alttext="h s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> genes was detected throughout the test period (data not shown). Figure 1. Average concentration of three <math alttext="m R N A s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="1, 2, 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I, II, III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) transcribed from genes in krill heat shocked at <math alttext="10 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mtext>10°C</mtext></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus, 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><msub><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Identify the <math alttext="h s p" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">hsp</mtext></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mRNA</mtext></math> that has the slowest rate of concentration increase in response to heat-shock treatment.
